task.title: [Project Tracker] Sensor configuration display UI

data.title: [Project Tracker] Sensor configuration display UI
data.body:
## Describe problem solved by the proposed feature
Currently it is hard to figure out which sensors are connected where, with which configuration and which priority (e.g. `CAL_MAG0_PRIO`) in a single view. For example during my [boat project](https://discuss.px4.io/t/rc-speed-boat-with-px4-episode-1-using-px4-to-control-the-boat/28429#things-that-are-still-ambiguous-to-me-22) build, I wasn't sure if I needed to set the priority of magnetometer manually or not.

This is also quite related to the calibration pain addressed in the issue #19459. What can we do to improve user experience for setting up the sensors? If so, which part should be addressed and how?

What could be great (in my opinion) could be something like this in QGC (it won't be a literal text output like this, but just for giving some idea):

```
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # First mag sensor
<mag-type> | <mag-orientation> | <mag-priority> | <mag-protocol?> # One for the second mag
<baro-type> |              | <baro-priority> | <baro-protocol>
<gyro-type> | <gyro-orientation> | <gyro-priority> | <gyro-protocol>
```

But I am also not sure what others expectation / needs are, so any feedback would be appreciated!

## Describe your preferred solution
* @davids5 pointed out that transferring device tree information over to QGC could be a solution. Could you elaborate on that?
* @dagar pointed out that having a unified view in general would be good. Could you let me know if a view I suggested above is similar to what you have imagined?

task.title: [feature]  Implement Session Tracking for Application and Window Usage

data.title: [feature]  Implement Session Tracking for Application and Window Usage
data.body:
## Challenge

I'm working on an application that requires accurate session tracking to analyze user behavior patterns,  and provide meaningful insights across different applications and windows. 

In the existing Screenpipe architecture, OCR data is stored with only timestamp information, lacking precise session boundaries (start/end times) for application usage tracking. This limitation prevents us from properly segmenting user activity into coherent sessions.

## 1. Current Workaround
internally I implementing a suboptimal solution that:
1. Queries all OCR database entries chronologically
2. Manually identifies session boundaries by analyzing timestamp sequences for each application
3. Determines session end when detecting a different application in subsequent timestamps
4. Assumes a session is ongoing if no clear delimiter exists in future timestamps

With that said I would love to hear any feedbacks that could help solve this problem with a minimal overhead on code changes, and make sure I'm not overthinking the solution: cc @louis030195 , i'm planning to start playing with some day next week

## 2. Requirements

1.  **Session Definition:** A "session" should be defined as a continuous period of user interaction with a specific application and window.  A break in activity (e.g., switching to a different application or window) should end the current session and potentially start a new one.  A configurable inactivity timeout (e.g., 5 minutes) should also end a session.

2.  **Data Storage:** The database schema must be modified to store session start and end times, associated with specific applications and windows.  It must maintain links to the relevant OCR and audio data chunks.

3.  **API Endpoint:**  A new or modified API endpoint (e.g., `/sessions`) is needed to query for session data.  This endpoint should support filtering by:
    *   Date range (start and end timestamps).
    *   Application name.
    *   Window name.
    *   Minimum and maximum session duration.
    *   Associated tags.
    *   Pagination (limit and offset).

4.  **Real-time Capability:** The system should be able to detect session boundaries in near real-time as data is being ingested. This implies integration with the existing data capture and processing pipeline.

5. **Configurability:** The inactivity timeout for ending a session should be configurable.

## 3. Proposed Solution

### 3.1. Database Schema Changes

We'll introduce a new table `sessions` and modify the existing tables.

**New Table: `sessions`**

| Column Name      | Data Type  | Constraints                                  | Description                                                                  |
| :--------------- | :--------- | :------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `id`             | INTEGER    | PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT                    | Unique identifier for the session.                                       |
| `app_name`       | TEXT       | NOT NULL                                     | Name of the application.                                                 |
| `window_name`    | TEXT       |                                               | Title of the window.                                                     |
| `start_time`     | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session start.                                            |
| `end_time`       | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session end.                                              |
| `duration_secs`  | REAL       | NOT NULL                                     | Duration of the session in seconds.                                        |

**Modified Tables:**

*   **`ocr_text`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`audio_transcriptions`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`ui_monitoring`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).

**Indexes:**

*   Create indexes on `sessions` table columns (`app_name`, `window_name`, `start_time`, `end_time`) for efficient querying.
*   Create indexes on the `session_id` columns in `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring`.

### 3.2. API Enhancements

We'll modify the existing `/search` endpoint to also support session queries.

**Request:**

```
GET /search?content_type=session&app_name=Cursor&start_time=2024-11-27T00:00:00Z&end_time=2024-11-28T00:00:00Z&min_duration=60&limit=10&offset=0
```

*   `content_type=session`: Indicates a session-based search.
*   `app_name`, `window_name`: Filter by application and window (optional).
*   `start_time`, `end_time`: Date range for the session (optional, defaults to last 24 hours).
*   `min_duration`, `max_duration`: Filter by session duration in seconds (optional).
*   `limit`, `offset`: Pagination parameters.


after discussing with @louis030195 on discord he proposed something like this as the output

**Response:**

```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "app_name": "Cursor",
      "total_usage_time": 3600,
      "windows": [
        {
          "window_name": "page.tsx",
          "sessions": [
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T12:00:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T12:30:00Z",
              "duration": 1800,
              "content_ids": [123, 124, 125],
              "tags": ["coding", "frontend"]
            },
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T14:00:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T14:30:00Z",
              "duration": 1800,
              "content_ids": [223, 224, 225],
              "tags": ["coding", "frontend"]
            }
          ],
          "total_usage_time": 3600
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "app_name": "Arc",
      "total_usage_time": 1200,
      "windows": [
        {
          "window_name": "x.com",
          "sessions": [
            {
              "start_time": "2024-07-16T10:30:00Z",
              "end_time": "2024-07-16T10:50:00Z",
              "duration": 1200,
              "content_ids": [126, 127, 128],
              "tags": ["browsing", "social-media"]
            }
          ],
          "total_usage_time": 1200
        }
      ]
    }
  ],
  "pagination": {
    "limit": 50,
    "offset": 0,
    "total": 2
  }
}
```

### 3.3. Session Boundary Detection Logic

1.  **Real-time Monitoring:**  The existing event listeners for OCR, audio, and UI events will be leveraged.

2.  **Session Tracking:**  Maintain a data structure (likely in memory, possibly augmented with periodic database writes for persistence) to track active sessions.  This structure should map:
    *   `(app_name, window_name)` -> `(session_id, last_activity_timestamp)`

3.  **New Event Handling:**
    *   When a new event (OCR, audio, UI) arrives:
        *   Extract `app_name` and `window_name`.
        *   Check if an active session exists for this (app, window) combination.
        *   If a session exists:
            *   Check if `now() - last_activity_timestamp` exceeds the inactivity timeout.
            *   If timeout exceeded, end the existing session and create a new one.
            *   If not timed out, update `last_activity_timestamp` to the event's timestamp.
        *   If no session exists:
            *   Create a new session with `start_time` and `end_time` set to the event's timestamp.
            *   Generate a new `session_id`.
            *   Insert a new row into the `sessions` table.
        *   Insert the new data (OCR, audio, UI) into the relevant table, linking it to the active `session_id`.

4.  **Inactivity Timeout:** A configurable timeout (e.g., 5 minutes) will be used to determine session end due to inactivity.

5.  **Periodic Flushing:** To avoid excessive in-memory state, periodically flush closed sessions (those that have exceeded the inactivity timeout) to the database.

6. **Data Migration:** A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records based on timestamp proximity and app/window changes.

### 3.4. Implementation Details

*   **Language/Framework:** Continue using Rust for core logic and database interaction.
*   **Database:** Continue using SQLite.
*   **Concurrency:** Use asynchronous operations with `tokio` for handling concurrent events and database interactions.  Leverage `Arc` and `Mutex` for shared state, and channels for communication between tasks.
*   **Configuration:** Add a new setting for the inactivity timeout.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement robust error handling with `anyhow` and propagate errors appropriately. Log errors using `tracing`.
* **Testing:** Thoroughly test session boundary detection with various scenarios, including rapid switching, long inactivity periods, and concurrent events.

## 4. Diagrams

### 4.1. Current Data Flow

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Database
    User->>Screen: Interacts with screen
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores OCR data with timestamps
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores audio transcriptions with timestamps
    User->>Screenpipe: Requests data
    Screenpipe->>Database: Queries data by time range
    Database->>Screenpipe: Returns data
    Screenpipe->>User: Returns data
```

### 4.2. Proposed Database Schema Changes

```mermaid
classDiagram
    class frames {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +video_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +name : TEXT
    }
    class video_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +device_name : TEXT
    }
    class ocr_text {
        +frame_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +text : TEXT
        +text_json : TEXT
        +app_name : TEXT
        +window_name : TEXT
        +ocr_engine : TEXT
        +focused : BOOLEAN
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class audio_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +timestamp : TIMESTAMP
    }
    class audio_transcriptions {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +audio_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +transcription : TEXT
        +device : TEXT
        +is_input_device : BOOLEAN
        +speaker_id : INTEGER
        +transcription_engine : TEXT
        +start_time : REAL
        +end_time : REAL
        +text_length : INTEGER
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class ui_monitoring {
      +id : INTEGER [PK]
      +text_output : TEXT
      +timestamp : DATETIME
      +app : TEXT
      +window : TEXT
      +initial_traversal_at : DATETIME
      +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
  class sessions {
    +id : INTEGER [PK]
    +app_name : TEXT
    +window_name : TEXT
    +start_time : DATETIME
    +end_time : DATETIME
    +duration_secs : REAL
  }
  frames --|> video_chunks : video_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> frames : frame_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> audio_chunks : audio_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> sessions : session_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> sessions : session_id
  ui_monitoring --|> sessions : session_id
```

### 4.3. Modified Data Flow with Session Tracking

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Session Manager
    participant Database

    User->>Screen: Interacts with App A, Window 1
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to session_id
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: Active session found (session_id)
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store audio data, link to session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: User switches to App B, Window 2
    User->>Screen: Interacts with App B, Window 2
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App B, Window 2)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: End previous session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to new session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: Inactivity Timeout
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for activity
    Session Manager->>Database: End current session (App B, Window 2)
```

### 4.4. New API Endpoint (Modified /search)

The existing `/search` endpoint will be extended to support session-based queries.  No new endpoint is needed.

## 5. Performance Implications

*   **Database:**  The addition of the `sessions` table and foreign keys will add some overhead to write operations.  Proper indexing is crucial to mitigate this.  Read performance for session-based queries should be good with appropriate indexes.
*   **Memory:**  The in-memory session tracking will require additional memory.  The size of this will depend on the number of concurrent users and the configured timeout.  This should be monitored and potentially optimized (e.g., using a more efficient data structure than a simple `HashMap`).
*   **CPU:**  The session boundary detection logic will add some CPU overhead.  This should be minimized by efficient checks and the use of asynchronous operations.

## 6. Migration Path

1.  **Add new `sessions` table.**
2.  **Add `session_id` columns** to `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring` tables.
3.  **Backfill `session_id`:**  A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records.  This script will need to:
    *   Iterate through existing OCR, audio, and UI data in chronological order.
    *   Apply the session boundary detection logic (described above) to group data into sessions.
    *   Insert corresponding rows into the `sessions` table.
    *   Update the `session_id` foreign key in the existing tables.


## 7. Alternative Approaches

1.  **Session Table per Content Type:** Instead of a single `sessions` table, we could have separate session tables for each content type (e.g., `ocr_sessions`, `audio_sessions`, `ui_sessions`).  This might simplify queries for a specific content type but could make cross-content type analysis more complex.
2.  **No Session Table (Denormalized):** We could add `start_time` and `end_time` directly to the existing tables (`ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, `ui_monitoring`). This would avoid the need for joins when querying for sessions, but could lead to data redundancy and potential inconsistencies.

5. **Configurability:** The inactivity timeout for ending a session should be configurable.

## 3. Proposed Solution

### 3.1. Database Schema Changes

We'll introduce a new table `sessions` and modify the existing tables.

**New Table: `sessions`**

| Column Name      | Data Type  | Constraints                                  | Description                                                                  |
| :--------------- | :--------- | :------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `id`             | INTEGER    | PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT                    | Unique identifier for the session.                                       |
| `app_name`       | TEXT       | NOT NULL                                     | Name of the application.                                                 |
| `window_name`    | TEXT       |                                               | Title of the window.                                                     |
| `start_time`     | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session start.                                            |
| `end_time`       | DATETIME   | NOT NULL                                     | Timestamp of the session end.                                              |
| `duration_secs`  | REAL       | NOT NULL                                     | Duration of the session in seconds.                                        |

**Modified Tables:**

*   **`ocr_text`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`audio_transcriptions`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).
*   **`ui_monitoring`**: Add a `session_id` column (INTEGER, FOREIGN KEY referencing `sessions.id`).

**Indexes:**

*   Create indexes on `sessions` table columns (`app_name`, `window_name`, `start_time`, `end_time`) for efficient querying.
*   Create indexes on the `session_id` columns in `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring`.

### 3.2. API Enhancements

We'll modify the existing `/search` endpoint to also support session queries.

**Request:**

```
GET /search?content_type=session&app_name=Cursor&start_time=2024-11-27T00:00:00Z&end_time=2024-11-28T00:00:00Z&min_duration=60&limit=10&offset=0
```

*   `content_type=session`: Indicates a session-based search.
*   `app_name`, `window_name`: Filter by application and window (optional).
*   `start_time`, `end_time`: Date range for the session (optional, defaults to last 24 hours).
*   `min_duration`, `max_duration`: Filter by session duration in seconds (optional).
*   `limit`, `offset`: Pagination parameters.

### 3.3. Session Boundary Detection Logic

1.  **Real-time Monitoring:**  The existing event listeners for OCR, audio, and UI events will be leveraged.

2.  **Session Tracking:**  Maintain a data structure (likely in memory, possibly augmented with periodic database writes for persistence) to track active sessions.  This structure should map:
    *   `(app_name, window_name)` -> `(session_id, last_activity_timestamp)`

3.  **New Event Handling:**
    *   When a new event (OCR, audio, UI) arrives:
        *   Extract `app_name` and `window_name`.
        *   Check if an active session exists for this (app, window) combination.
        *   If a session exists:
            *   Check if `now() - last_activity_timestamp` exceeds the inactivity timeout.
            *   If timeout exceeded, end the existing session and create a new one.
            *   If not timed out, update `last_activity_timestamp` to the event's timestamp.
        *   If no session exists:
            *   Create a new session with `start_time` and `end_time` set to the event's timestamp.
            *   Generate a new `session_id`.
            *   Insert a new row into the `sessions` table.
        *   Insert the new data (OCR, audio, UI) into the relevant table, linking it to the active `session_id`.

4.  **Inactivity Timeout:** A configurable timeout (e.g., 5 minutes) will be used to determine session end due to inactivity.

5.  **Periodic Flushing:** To avoid excessive in-memory state, periodically flush closed sessions (those that have exceeded the inactivity timeout) to the database.

6. **Data Migration:** A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records based on timestamp proximity and app/window changes.

### 3.4. Implementation Details

*   **Language/Framework:** Continue using Rust for core logic and database interaction.
*   **Database:** Continue using SQLite.
*   **Concurrency:** Use asynchronous operations with `tokio` for handling concurrent events and database interactions.  Leverage `Arc` and `Mutex` for shared state, and channels for communication between tasks.
*   **Configuration:** Add a new setting for the inactivity timeout.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement robust error handling with `anyhow` and propagate errors appropriately. Log errors using `tracing`.
* **Testing:** Thoroughly test session boundary detection with various scenarios, including rapid switching, long inactivity periods, and concurrent events.

## 4. Diagrams

### 4.1. Current Data Flow

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Database
    User->>Screen: Interacts with screen
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores OCR data with timestamps
    Screenpipe->>Database: Stores audio transcriptions with timestamps
    User->>Screenpipe: Requests data
    Screenpipe->>Database: Queries data by time range
    Database->>Screenpipe: Returns data
    Screenpipe->>User: Returns data
```

### 4.2. Proposed Database Schema Changes

```mermaid
classDiagram
    class frames {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +video_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +name : TEXT
    }
    class video_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +device_name : TEXT
    }
    class ocr_text {
        +frame_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +text : TEXT
        +text_json : TEXT
        +app_name : TEXT
        +window_name : TEXT
        +ocr_engine : TEXT
        +focused : BOOLEAN
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class audio_chunks {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +file_path : TEXT
        +timestamp : TIMESTAMP
    }
    class audio_transcriptions {
        +id : INTEGER [PK]
        +audio_chunk_id : INTEGER [FK]
        +offset_index : INTEGER
        +timestamp : DATETIME
        +transcription : TEXT
        +device : TEXT
        +is_input_device : BOOLEAN
        +speaker_id : INTEGER
        +transcription_engine : TEXT
        +start_time : REAL
        +end_time : REAL
        +text_length : INTEGER
        +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
    class ui_monitoring {
      +id : INTEGER [PK]
      +text_output : TEXT
      +timestamp : DATETIME
      +app : TEXT
      +window : TEXT
      +initial_traversal_at : DATETIME
      +session_id : INTEGER [FK]
    }
  class sessions {
    +id : INTEGER [PK]
    +app_name : TEXT
    +window_name : TEXT
    +start_time : DATETIME
    +end_time : DATETIME
    +duration_secs : REAL
  }
  frames --|> video_chunks : video_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> frames : frame_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> audio_chunks : audio_chunk_id
  ocr_text --|> sessions : session_id
  audio_transcriptions --|> sessions : session_id
  ui_monitoring --|> sessions : session_id
```

### 4.3. Modified Data Flow with Session Tracking

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Screen
    participant Microphone
    participant Screenpipe
    participant Session Manager
    participant Database

    User->>Screen: Interacts with App A, Window 1
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to session_id
    User->>Microphone: Speaks
    Microphone->>Screenpipe: Captures audio
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: Active session found (session_id)
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store audio data, link to session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: User switches to App B, Window 2
    User->>Screen: Interacts with App B, Window 2
    Screen->>Screenpipe: Captures screen content (OCR)
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for existing session (App B, Window 2)
    Session Manager-->>Screenpipe: No active session
    Session Manager->>Database: End previous session (App A, Window 1)
    Session Manager->>Database: Create new session, get session_id
    Screenpipe->>Database: Store OCR data, link to new session_id

    Note over User,Screenpipe: Inactivity Timeout
    Screenpipe->>Session Manager: Check for activity
    Session Manager->>Database: End current session (App B, Window 2)
```

### 4.4. New API Endpoint (Modified /search)

The existing `/search` endpoint will be extended to support session-based queries.  No new endpoint is needed.

## 5. Performance Implications

*   **Database:**  The addition of the `sessions` table and foreign keys will add some overhead to write operations.  Proper indexing is crucial to mitigate this.  Read performance for session-based queries should be good with appropriate indexes.
*   **Memory:**  The in-memory session tracking will require additional memory.  The size of this will depend on the number of concurrent users and the configured timeout.  This should be monitored and potentially optimized (e.g., using a more efficient data structure than a simple `HashMap`).
*   **CPU:**  The session boundary detection logic will add some CPU overhead.  This should be minimized by efficient checks and the use of asynchronous operations.

## 6. Migration Path

1.  **Add new `sessions` table.**
2.  **Add `session_id` columns** to `ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, and `ui_monitoring` tables.
3.  **Backfill `session_id`:**  A migration script will be needed to analyze existing data and create initial session records.  This script will need to:
    *   Iterate through existing OCR, audio, and UI data in chronological order.
    *   Apply the session boundary detection logic (described above) to group data into sessions.
    *   Insert corresponding rows into the `sessions` table.
    *   Update the `session_id` foreign key in the existing tables.


## 7. Alternative Approaches

1.  **Session Table per Content Type:** Instead of a single `sessions` table, we could have separate session tables for each content type (e.g., `ocr_sessions`, `audio_sessions`, `ui_sessions`).  This might simplify queries for a specific content type but could make cross-content type analysis more complex.
2.  **No Session Table (Denormalized):** We could add `start_time` and `end_time` directly to the existing tables (`ocr_text`, `audio_transcriptions`, `ui_monitoring`). This would avoid the need for joins when querying for sessions, but could lead to data redundancy and potential inconsistencies.

data.body:
## Problem

This is a situation that can happen:
```
--- yarn prisma -v ---
warning package.json: No license field
prisma               : 2.26.0-dev.7
@prisma/client       : 2.26.0-dev.7
Current platform     : debian-openssl-1.1.x
Query Engine         : query-engine c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/query-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Migration Engine     : migration-engine-cli c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/migration-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Introspection Engine : introspection-core c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/introspection-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Format Binary        : prisma-fmt c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/prisma-fmt-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Default Engines Hash : c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922
Studio               : 0.402.0
--- ls node_modules/@prisma/engines/ ---
ls: cannot access 'node_modules/@prisma/engines/': No such file or directory
```

As you can see `yarn prisma -v` tells us the engines comes from `node_modules/@prisma/engines`, but when you try to list that directory, it is actually not present.

What is happening here is that `yarn prisma` is actually from a few folders _above_ our project. This is kinda visible when you look to not run `yarn -s` but just `yarn`:
```
codespace  /workspaces/e2e-tests/platforms-serverless/firebase-functions (janpio-patch-5 ) $ yarn prisma -v
yarn run v1.22.10
warning package.json: No license field
$ /workspaces/e2e-tests/node_modules/.bin/prisma -v
prisma               : 2.25.0-dev.36
@prisma/client       : 2.25.0-dev.36
...
```

## Suggested solution

Output the directory of where the executed `prisma` is from, either similar to Yarn the absolute path to the binary in `node_modules`, or the folder where the `package.json` that is responsible for the installation of Prisma comes from.

## Alternatives

Rely on `yarn` itself to give that information. Will not work with `npx` unfortunately for example.

```
prisma               : 2.25.0-dev.36
@prisma/client       : 2.25.0-dev.36
...
```

## Suggested solution

Output the directory of where the executed `prisma` is from, either similar to Yarn the absolute path to the binary in `node_modules`, or the folder where the `package.json` that is responsible for the installation of Prisma comes from.

## Alternatives

Rely on `yarn` itself to give that information. Will not work with `npx` unfortunately for example.

task.title: Incorporate MCP Server into Golem CLI

data.title: Incorporate MCP Server into Golem CLI
data.body:
With a new command, Golem CLI enters serve mode:

```bash
%> golem-cli --serve --serve-port 1232
%> golem-cli running MCP Server at port 1232
```

In this mode, Golem CLI creates an MCP Server that exposes different commands as different tools, and exposes relevant resources (the manifest file in the current, ancestor, and children directories) as resources.

When this ticket is completed, it should be possible to use an agent such as Claude Code to perform anything that Golem CLI can do. Moreover, all individual tools and resources must be end-to-end tested with an MCP Client that interacts with the MCP Server.

[This library](https://github.com/rust-mcp-stack/rust-mcp-sdk) looks like the one to use for Rust, but perhaps there are better options available.
